title: _act_
author: _act_
content: Hong Kong lawmaker Wu Jie wanted this and has urged the city-state’s government to consider integrating bitcoin into its fiscal reserves, a local media outlet reported.You can read the news yourself here if you do not want to read the PDF: https://cryptoslate.com/hong-kong-lawmaker-advocates-including-bitcoin-in-national-reserves/Wu Jie said bitcoin strategic reserve  might reduce reliance on traditional reserves like gold and silver, as bitcoin’s lower storage and transaction costs present a practical advantage, he explained.QuoteMoreover, if “influential” countries adopt Bitcoin, its value will stabilize to an extent that prompts wider acceptance globally. This shift might reduce reliance on traditional reserves like gold and silver, as Bitcoin’s lower storage and transaction costs present a practical advantage, he explained.More countries lawmakers are proposing bitcoin strategic reserve.https://cryptoslate.com/hong-kong-lawmaker-advocates-including-bitcoin-in-national-reserves/

comments.author: Richbased
comments.body: Quote from: _act_ on December 30, 2024, 10:19:01 AMMore countries lawmakers are proposing bitcoin strategic reserve.Inauguration day is near, what should we expect if not news about countries making a proposal for Bitcoin strategic reserve. I mean, no developed or developing  countries would want to be left behind in this new transition that the Global economy is gonna experience through the enactment of laws that will support Bitcoin and it's possible adoption by the incoming government of Donald Trump. We are yet to hear more positive news about proposals for Bitcoin's strategic reserve either before the inauguration date or after.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: I would like to know if there are any opponents to this and what their reasons could be. Topic I commented on a thread on bitcoin supercycle. I know that if Bitcoin is included in national reserves of countries, one of the results is that we could enter in a bitcoin supercycle but what are opponents of this saying. This could mean imposed regulatory infrastructure which could also discourage global adoption (at least this is something that came to mind). But then we just need the US and another nation to add bitcoin to it national reserves for other countries to follow. The world bank has already said crypto assets are unfit as reserve, I'll wait to hear if they will change their stance, should the U.S go ahead to include bitcoin.

comments.author: retreat
comments.body: With more and more lawmakers starting to show their interest in Bitcoin as a strategic reserve for the country, it shows how Bitcoin is starting to be considered as something important and can be the best option for investment diversification. This is certainly positive news, because if this bill is passed, it means that Bitcoin is starting to be recognized by more people and strengthens its position. And directly it will increase the adoption of Bitcoin in the future.

comments.author: Maslate
comments.body: This all started when a US senator proposed making Bitcoin a national reserve. With other countries considering the same, we might see massive accumulation in the future if this law gets passed. I really hope Trump takes action on this next year so the US can lead, making it easier for smaller countries to follow.This could be the massive adoption we’ve been waiting for, but it’s the institutions and countries showing more interest. In the end, this will likely push the price higher while also increasing demand for daily use. Hopefully, this reduces manipulation in the market. Next year will be a crucial year to see Bitcoin’s full performance, let's wait and see.

comments.author: Swordsoffreedom
comments.body: Quote from: Davidvictorson on December 30, 2024, 10:48:25 AMI would like to know if there are any opponents to this and what their reasons could be. Topic I commented on a thread on bitcoin supercycle. I know that if Bitcoin is included in national reserves of countries, one of the results is that we could enter in a bitcoin supercycle but what are opponents of this saying. This could mean imposed regulatory infrastructure which could also discourage global adoption (at least this is something that came to mind). But then we just need the US and another nation to add bitcoin to it national reserves for other countries to follow. The world bank has already said crypto assets are unfit as reserve, I'll wait to hear if they will change their stance, should the U.S go ahead to include bitcoin.Not only the World Bank, the US Federal Reserve also issued a statement that they have no right and no intention to use bitcoin as a national reserve. I'm waiting to see how Trump will convince Congress to change the law so the Fed can add bitcoin to the US reserves. If the United States succeeds in including bitcoin in its national reserves, other countries will surely follow suit as the United States is the world leader and is considered to be the trendsetter. But the question of what the Trump administration will do to make that happen is what we need to worry about first. The Federal Reserve is the custodian of the nation's reserves and only Congress can make them change their mind, the president has no authority to make a decision on this matter on his own.

comments.author: Ziskinberg
comments.body: Quote from: cryptomaniac_xxx on December 30, 2024, 12:47:24 PMFor me, I think what who might opposed this is that Bitcoin is very volatile, so there could be politicians that might say that this is not going to work for them as they are going to lose money if they invested on it.That’s true, especially if they’re not from the same party, it all comes down to numbers. Majority wins, after all.Speaking of volatility, Bitcoin is still volatile, but it’s been less volatile this year. That’s definitely progress and should be seen as a good sign for everyone keeping an eye on it.Quote from: cryptomaniac_xxx on December 30, 2024, 12:47:24 PMAnd only the country El Salvador has really advocated Bitcoin as legal tender and still, there are reports that it's really a bad decision for Bukele about this experiment. On the flip side, the country is still continuing it's massive haul and buying and in this bull run, it going to be worth billions.The US is also a good example, but so far, the Fed is in opposition on Trump's decision to Bitcoin as a national reserve. But let's see what happens next year when Trumps officially sits in.Using Bitcoin as a national reserve does come with risks, so countries would definitely employ risk management strategies. It’s not like they’d put all their funds into Bitcoin but just a portion, treating it as an investment. They’d likely only allocate what they can afford to lose, similar to how individual investors approach it.As for El Salvador, the criticism is pretty normal, especially since it’s tied to politics, but now their decision seems to be paying off, as their Bitcoin accumulation is profitable at the current prices.
